#### 1.2a Definition of Forces

In the previous section, we introduced the concept of forces and their measurement. In this section, we will delve deeper into the definition of forces and their role in mechanics.

A force is a vector quantity that describes the interaction between two objects. It is represented by the symbol $F$ and is defined as the product of the mass of an object and its acceleration. This relationship is known as Newton's Second Law of Motion, which states that the force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object times its acceleration. Mathematically, this can be expressed as:

$$
F = ma
$$

where $F$ is the force, $m$ is the mass of the object, and $a$ is the acceleration of the object.

Forces can be classified into two types: contact forces and non-contact forces. Contact forces, such as friction and tension, require physical contact between two objects. Non-contact forces, such as gravity and electromagnetism, can act on objects without physical contact.

In addition to their role in describing the interaction between objects, forces also play a crucial role in determining the equilibrium of a system. Equilibrium is a state in which all forces acting on a system are balanced, resulting in no net force or acceleration. This concept is essential in statics, as it allows us to analyze and predict the behavior of objects under different loading conditions.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of equilibrium in more detail and introduce the concept of free-body diagrams, which are essential tools for analyzing the forces acting on a system.

#### 1.2b Types of Forces

In the previous section, we discussed the definition of forces and their role in mechanics. In this section, we will explore the different types of forces that can act on a system.

As mentioned earlier, forces can be classified into two types: contact forces and non-contact forces. Contact forces, such as friction and tension, require physical contact between two objects. Non-contact forces, such as gravity and electromagnetism, can act on objects without physical contact.

Contact forces can be further classified into two types: conservative and non-conservative. Conservative forces, such as gravity and spring forces, do not dissipate energy when acting on a system. This means that the total energy of the system remains constant when acted upon by a conservative force. Non-conservative forces, such as friction and air resistance, dissipate energy and can change the total energy of the system.

Non-contact forces can also be classified into two types: central and non-central. Central forces, such as gravity and electromagnetism, act along a single axis or line. Non-central forces, such as air resistance and friction, can act in any direction.

In addition to these classifications, forces can also be categorized based on their direction. Forces can be either parallel or perpendicular to the axis of rotation. Parallel forces act along the same axis and can either be in the same direction (concurrent forces) or in opposite directions (opposed forces). Perpendicular forces act at right angles to the axis of rotation and can either be in the same direction (concurrent forces) or in opposite directions (opposed forces).

Understanding the different types of forces and their properties is crucial in analyzing the equilibrium of a system. In the next section, we will explore the concept of equilibrium in more detail and introduce the concept of free-body diagrams, which are essential tools for analyzing the forces acting on a system.

#### 1.2b Definition of Moments

In the previous section, we discussed the definition of forces and their role in mechanics. In this section, we will explore the concept of moments and their role in equilibrium analysis.

A moment is a measure of the tendency of a force to cause rotation about a specific point or axis. It is represented by the symbol $M$ and is defined as the product of the magnitude of a force and the perpendicular distance from the point or axis of rotation. Mathematically, this can be expressed as:

$$
M = F \times d
$$

where $M$ is the moment, $F$ is the magnitude of the force, and $d$ is the perpendicular distance from the point or axis of rotation.

Moments can be either clockwise or counterclockwise, depending on the direction of rotation. A positive moment indicates a clockwise rotation, while a negative moment indicates a counterclockwise rotation.

In equilibrium analysis, moments play a crucial role in determining the stability of a system. A system is in equilibrium when the sum of all moments acting on it is equal to zero. This means that the system is not rotating and is either at rest or moving at a constant velocity.

Moments can also be used to determine the point or axis of rotation for a system. The point or axis of rotation is the point or line about which the system is rotating. It can be determined by setting the sum of all moments equal to zero and solving for the unknown point or axis of rotation.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of equilibrium in more detail and introduce the concept of free-body diagrams, which are essential tools for analyzing the forces and moments acting on a system.

#### 1.2c Types of Moments

In the previous section, we discussed the definition of moments and their role in equilibrium analysis. In this section, we will explore the different types of moments that can act on a system.

There are two types of moments that can act on a system: clockwise moments and counterclockwise moments. As mentioned earlier, a positive moment indicates a clockwise rotation, while a negative moment indicates a counterclockwise rotation.

Clockwise moments are moments that cause rotation in a clockwise direction. They are typically caused by forces acting on a system in a counterclockwise direction. For example, if a force is acting on a system to the left of the point or axis of rotation, it will cause a clockwise moment.

Counterclockwise moments are moments that cause rotation in a counterclockwise direction. They are typically caused by forces acting on a system in a clockwise direction. For example, if a force is acting on a system to the right of the point or axis of rotation, it will cause a counterclockwise moment.

In equilibrium analysis, it is important to consider both clockwise and counterclockwise moments. The sum of all moments acting on a system must be equal to zero for the system to be in equilibrium. This means that the system must have an equal number of clockwise and counterclockwise moments.

Moments can also be classified as external moments or internal moments. External moments are caused by forces acting on the system from outside, while internal moments are caused by forces acting between different parts of the system. In equilibrium analysis, it is important to consider both external and internal moments. The sum of all external moments must be equal to the sum of all internal moments for the system to be in equilibrium.

To better understand this concept, let us consider a simple example. Imagine a uniform rod of length $L$ and mass $m$ hinged at one end and supported by a pivot at the other end. $$

Next, let us consider the moments acting on the rod. The only moment acting on the rod is the moment of inertia of the rod about the pivot. This moment is equal to $\frac{1}{3}mL^2$ and is clockwise. #### 1.3b Types of Equilibrium

There are three types of equilibrium: static, dynamic, and thermal equilibrium. Each type of equilibrium is characterized by different conditions and is essential in understanding the behavior of systems.

##### Static Equilibrium

As we have discussed in the previous sections, static equilibrium is a state in which a system is at rest or moving at a constant velocity. This is achieved when the sum of all forces acting on the system is equal to zero, and the sum of all moments acting on the system is also equal to zero. This can be mathematically expressed as:

$$
\sum F = 0
$$

$$
\sum M = 0
$$

Static equilibrium is crucial in mechanics and materials as it allows us to analyze and predict the behavior of systems under different loading conditions. By understanding the forces and moments acting on a system, we can determine whether it will be in equilibrium or not. This is essential in designing structures and machines that can withstand the forces and moments acting on them.

##### Dynamic Equilibrium

Dynamic equilibrium is a state in which a system is moving at a constant velocity. This is achieved when the sum of all forces acting on the system is equal to zero, and the sum of all moments acting on the system is also equal to zero. However, unlike static equilibrium, the system is not at rest. This can be mathematically expressed as:

$$
\sum F = 0
$$

$$
\sum M = 0
$$

Dynamic equilibrium is important in understanding the behavior of systems that are moving, such as vehicles and machines. By analyzing the forces and moments acting on a system, we can determine whether it will be in dynamic equilibrium or not. This is crucial in designing systems that can move efficiently and safely.

##### Thermal Equilibrium

Thermal equilibrium is a state in which a system is at a constant temperature. This is achieved when the sum of all heat transfer rates into the system is equal to the sum of all heat transfer rates out of the system. This can be mathematically expressed as:

$$
\sum \dot{Q}_{in} = \sum \dot{Q}_{out}
$$

where $\dot{Q}_{in}$ is the heat transfer rate into the system and $\dot{Q}_{out}$ is the heat transfer rate out of the system.

Thermal equilibrium is important in understanding the behavior of systems that involve heat transfer, such as engines and refrigeration systems. By analyzing the heat transfer rates into and out of a system, we can determine whether it will be in thermal equilibrium or not. This is crucial in designing systems that can maintain a constant temperature and efficiently transfer heat.

Shear force is a type of force that occurs when two forces act parallel to each other but in opposite directions. $$

This method is based on the principle of virtual work, which states that the work done by the external forces on a structure is equal to the internal strain energy stored in the structure. The method of consistent deformations involves the construction of a shear and moment diagram, and the use of the principle of virtual work to solve for the unknown forces and deformations.

The slope-deflection method is another graphical method that is used to solve for the unknown forces and deformations in a structure. This method is based on the principle of superposition, which states that the total deflection of a structure is equal to the sum of the deflections caused by each individual load acting alone. The slope-deflection method involves the construction of a slope and deflection diagram, and the use of the principle of superposition to solve for the unknown forces and deformations.

The moment distribution method is a numerical method that is used to solve for the unknown forces and deformations in a structure. This method is based on the principle of equilibrium, which states that the sum of the forces acting on a structure is equal to zero. The moment distribution method involves the distribution of the moments along the length of the structure, and the use of the principle of equilibrium to solve for the unknown forces and deformations.

#### 2.2c Solving Static Indeterminacy Problems

Solving static indeterminacy problems involves a systematic approach that combines the principles of equilibrium, compatibility, and material properties. The process can be broken down into the following steps:

1. **Identify the unknowns**: The first step in solving any indeterminate problem is to identify the unknown forces and deformations. In the case of the beam construction, the unknown reactions ($V_A$, $V_B$, $V_C$, and $H_A$) and the unknown deformations are the unknowns.

2. **Apply the equilibrium equations**: The equilibrium equations can be used to eliminate some of the unknowns. For instance, the sum of the vertical forces and the sum of the horizontal forces can be set to zero to eliminate $V_A$ and $H_A$. This results in the following equations:

$$
\begin{align*}
V_B + V_C - 1000 &= 0 \\
H_B - 500 &= 0 \\
\end{align*}
$$

3. **Apply the compatibility equations**: The compatibility equations can be used to eliminate the unknown deformations. For instance, the deformation of the beam at $A$ and $B$ can be set to zero to eliminate the unknown deformations. This results in the following equations:

$$
\begin{align*}
\frac{V_A}{EI} - \frac{V_B}{EI} &= 0 \\
\frac{V_A}{EI} - \frac{V_B + V_C}{EI} &= 0 \\
\end{align*}
$$

4. **Solve the resulting system of equations**: The system of equations obtained from the equilibrium and compatibility equations can be solved to obtain the unknown forces and deformations. This can be done using various methods, such as the method of consistent deformations or the slope-deflection method.

5. **Check the results**: The results obtained from the solution of the system of equations should satisfy all the equilibrium and compatibility equations. If they do not, the solution is not correct and should be rechecked.

In the next section, we will discuss some common methods for solving static indeterminacy problems, including the method of consistent deformations and the slope-deflection method.




#### 2.3a Advanced Static Indeterminacy Problems

#### 2.3a.1 Superposition Method

The superposition method is a powerful technique for solving static indeterminacy problems. It is based on the principle of superposition, which states that the total response of a system is equal to the sum of the individual responses caused by each input acting alone.

The superposition method can be applied to problems where the system can be divided into simpler subsystems, each of which can be analyzed separately. The total response of the system is then obtained by summing the responses of the individual subsystems.

For example, consider the beam construction problem discussed in the previous section. The beam can be divided into two subsystems: the section between $A$ and $B$, and the section between $B$ and $C$. The reactions at $A$ and $B$ can be determined separately for each subsystem, and then summed to obtain the total reactions.

#### 2.3a.2 Method of Consistent Deformations

The method of consistent deformations is another powerful technique for solving static indeterminacy problems. It is based on the principle of virtual work, which states that the work done by external forces on a system is equal to the internal strain energy stored in the system.

The method of consistent deformations involves the following steps:

1. Assume a deformation pattern for the system.
2. Calculate the strain energy due to this deformation pattern.
3. Set the strain energy equal to the work done by external forces.
4. Solve the resulting equations to obtain the unknown forces and deformations.

For example, consider the beam construction problem discussed in the previous section. Assume a deformation pattern where the beam deforms uniformly between $A$ and $B$, and between $B$ and $C$. The strain energy due to this deformation pattern can be calculated, and set equal to the work done by external forces. The resulting equations can then be solved to obtain the unknown reactions and deformations.

1. Divide the system into a series of sections.
2. Calculate the slope and deflection at the ends of each section.
3. Set the slope and deflection equal to the work done by external forces.
4. Solve the resulting equations to obtain the unknown forces and deformations.

The beam can be divided into a series of sections, and the slope and deflection at the ends of each section can be calculated. #### 2.3b Uniaxial Loading

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of static indeterminacy and how it can be solved using various techniques. In this section, we will focus on a specific type of loading condition known as uniaxial loading.

Uniaxial loading is a type of loading condition where a structure is subjected to a single axial force. This type of loading is common in many engineering applications, such as in the design of columns, beams, and pressure vessels.

The behavior of a structure under uniaxial loading can be described using the equations of equilibrium and compatibility. These equations can be used to determine the internal forces and deformations within the structure.

#### 2.3b.1 Equations of Equilibrium

The equations of equilibrium are fundamental to the analysis of structures under any type of loading condition. For uniaxial loading, the equations of equilibrium can be written as:

$$
\sum F = 0
$$

$$
\sum M = 0
$$

where $\sum F$ is the sum of all forces acting on the structure, and $\sum M$ is the sum of all moments acting on the structure. These equations can be used to determine the reactions at the supports of the structure, as well as the internal forces within the structure.

#### 2.3b.2 Equations of Compatibility

The equations of compatibility are used to determine the deformations within a structure. For uniaxial loading, the equations of compatibility can be written as:

$$
\Delta = \frac{\Delta L}{EI}
$$

where $\Delta$ is the deformation, $\Delta L$ is the change in length, $E$ is the modulus of elasticity, and $I$ is the moment of inertia. These equations can be used to determine the deformations within the structure, which are essential for designing structures that can withstand the applied loads.

#### 2.3b.3 Material Properties

The behavior of a structure under uniaxial loading is also influenced by the material properties of the structure. The material properties, such as the modulus of elasticity and yield strength, determine the ability of the structure to withstand the applied loads.

For example, a structure made of a material with a high modulus of elasticity will be more resistant to deformation under uniaxial loading than a structure made of a material with a low modulus of elasticity. Similarly, a structure made of a material with a high yield strength will be able to withstand higher loads before failure than a structure made of a material with a low yield strength.

In the next section, we will discuss how these concepts can be applied to solve specific problems involving uniaxial loading.




#### 2.3c Material Properties under Uniaxial Loading

In the previous section, we discussed the equations of equilibrium and compatibility, which are essential for analyzing the behavior of structures under uniaxial loading. However, the material properties of the structure also play a crucial role in determining its response to loading.

The material properties under uniaxial loading can be categorized into two types: elastic properties and plastic properties.

#### 2.3c.1 Elastic Properties

Elastic properties describe the behavior of a material under small deformations, where the material returns to its original shape after the load is removed. The most important elastic property is the modulus of elasticity, denoted by $E$. It is a measure of the stiffness of the material and is defined as the ratio of stress to strain:

$$
E = \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon}
$$

where $\sigma$ is the stress and $\epsilon$ is the strain. The modulus of elasticity is a material property that can vary significantly between different materials. For example, steel has a much higher modulus of elasticity than rubber, which means that steel is much stiffer and can withstand larger stresses before deforming.

#### 2.3c.2 Plastic Properties

Plastic properties describe the behavior of a material under large deformations, where the material does not return to its original shape after the load is removed. The most important plastic property is the yield strength, denoted by $y_s$. It is the stress at which a material begins to deform plastically. The yield strength is a critical property for designing structures, as it determines the maximum stress that a material can withstand before permanent deformation.

#### 2.3c.3 Unified Strength Theory

The unified strength theory (UST) is a mathematical model that describes the failure of materials under uniaxial loading. It is based on the concept of twin-shear stress, which is a combination of the normal and shear stresses in a material. The UST is particularly useful for analyzing the failure of materials under complex loading conditions, such as in the case of reinforced concrete.

The UST can be derived from the twin-shear element models proposed by Mao-Hong Yu. These models represent the twin-shear stress state and can be used to derive the unified strength theory. The UST is given by:

$$
F = {\tau _{13} + b{\tau _{12}} + \beta ({\sigma _{13}} + b{\sigma _{12}}) = C, {\text{ when }} {\tau _{12}} + \beta {\sigma _{12}} \geqslant {\tau _{23}} + \beta {\sigma _{23}}</math>}}<right|(3a)><br>
F' = {\tau _{13} + b{\tau _{23}} + \beta ({\sigma _{13}} + b{\sigma _{23}}) = C, {\text{ when }}{\tau _{12}} + \beta {\sigma _{12}} \leqslant {\tau _{23}} + \beta {\sigma _{23}}</math>}}<right|(3b)><br>
$$

where $F$ and $F'$ are the failure criteria for the UST, $\tau_{13}$ and $\tau_{12}$ are the shear stresses, $\sigma_{13}$ and $\sigma_{12}$ are the normal stresses, $b$ and $\beta$ are material parameters, and $C$ is the critical stress. The values of $b$ and $\beta$ can be determined from uniaxial failure tests.

The UST has been successfully applied to the analysis of various structures, including reinforced concrete, steel, and composite materials. It provides a powerful tool for understanding the failure of materials under uniaxial loading and can be used to design structures that are safe and reliable.




#### 2.4a Definition of Trusses

A truss is a structural system that is commonly used in engineering and architecture. It is composed of a series of interconnected members, typically in the form of beams, that are connected at their ends by nodes. The members and nodes are organized in such a way that the assemblage behaves as a single object, with the members experiencing forces that are either tensile or compressive.

The term "truss" is derived from the Old French word "trousse", which means "collection of things bound together". In the context of engineering, a truss is often defined as a single plane framework of individual structural members connected at their ends to form a series of triangles. This configuration is essential for the truss to behave as a rigid body, capable of spanning large distances.

Trusses are typically composed of five or more triangular units, with straight members extending from the top to the bottom of the structure. The top beams, known as "top chords", are typically in compression, while the bottom beams, known as "bottom chords", are typically in tension. The interior beams, known as "webs", and the areas inside the webs, known as "panels", are crucial for the structural integrity of the truss.

The etymology of the term "truss" can be traced back to the 12th century, with the earliest recorded use in the 11th century. The term has been used to describe various structures, including a cruck frame or a couple of rafters, but it is now commonly associated with the truss structure as we know it today.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the analysis of trusses, exploring the forces and moments transmitted by the members, and how these forces and moments can be calculated using the principles of statics and mechanics.

#### 2.4b Types of Trusses

There are several types of trusses, each with its own unique characteristics and applications. The most common types include the Howe truss, the Allan truss, and the Prussian truss.

##### Howe Truss

The Howe truss, named after its inventor, is a variation of the Prussian truss. It is a subclass of the Prussian truss, and is often used in the construction of bridges. The Howe truss is characterized by its use of a single top chord, which is connected to the bottom chords by a series of vertical members. This configuration allows for a more efficient use of materials, making the Howe truss a popular choice for long-span bridges.

##### Allan Truss

The Allan truss, named after its inventor, is another variation of the Prussian truss. It is also a subclass of the Prussian truss, and is often used in the construction of roofs. The Allan truss is characterized by its use of a series of horizontal members, known as "lateral bracing", which are connected to the top chord. This configuration provides additional support to the truss, making it suitable for use in roof structures.

##### Prussian Truss

The Prussian truss, named after its origin in Prussia, is a classic example of a truss structure. It is characterized by its use of two top chords, which are connected to the bottom chords by a series of horizontal members. The Prussian truss is often used in the construction of bridges and roofs, and is known for its simplicity and strength.

Each of these truss types has its own unique characteristics, and the choice of truss type depends on the specific requirements of the structure. In the next section, we will explore the deformations that occur in truss structures, and how these deformations can be calculated using the principles of mechanics and materials.

#### 2.4c Deformations in Trusses

Trusses, like any other structural system, are subject to deformations under load. These deformations can be categorized into two types: elastic deformations and plastic deformations. Elastic deformations are temporary and reversible, while plastic deformations are permanent and can lead to structural failure if not properly accounted for in the design.

##### Elastic Deformations

Elastic deformations in trusses are primarily due to the stretching and bending of the members under load. The magnitude of these deformations can be calculated using the principles of statics and mechanics. For example, the elastic deformation of a member under tensile or compressive load can be calculated using Hooke's Law, which states that the deformation of a member is directly proportional to the applied load. Mathematically, this can be represented as:

$$
\Delta = \frac{FL}{AE}
$$

where $\Delta$ is the elastic deformation, $F$ is the applied load, $L$ is the length of the member, $A$ is the cross-sectional area of the member, and $E$ is the modulus of elasticity of the material.

##### Plastic Deformations

Plastic deformations in trusses, on the other hand, are due to the permanent change in shape of the members under load. These deformations can lead to structural failure if not properly accounted for in the design. The magnitude of these deformations can be calculated using the principles of plasticity, which is a branch of mechanics that deals with the behavior of materials under large deformations.

One common method for calculating plastic deformations in trusses is the finite element method. This method involves dividing the truss into a series of finite elements, and then solving for the deformations of each element using numerical techniques. The results are then combined to obtain the overall deformation of the truss.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of stress and strain in trusses, and how these quantities are related to the deformations discussed in this section.




#### 2.4b Truss Deformations

Trusses, like any other structural system, are subject to deformations under load. These deformations can be significant, especially in large-scale structures, and understanding them is crucial for the design and analysis of trusses.

The deformations in a truss can be categorized into two types: elastic deformations and plastic deformations. Elastic deformations are temporary and reversible, while plastic deformations are permanent and can lead to structural failure if not properly accounted for in the design.

The elastic deformations in a truss are primarily due to the stretching and bending of the members under load. The stretching of a member can be modeled using Hooke's Law, which states that the strain in a member is directly proportional to the applied stress. The bending of a member, on the other hand, can be modeled using the flexure formula, which relates the bending moment to the cross-sectional area of the member and its material properties.

The plastic deformations in a truss, on the other hand, are primarily due to the yielding of the members under load. The yielding of a member occurs when the applied stress exceeds the yield strength of the member. Once a member has yielded, it will deform permanently under the applied load, even after the load is removed.

The deformations in a truss can be calculated using the principles of statics and mechanics. The deformation of a member can be calculated by integrating the strain over the length of the member. The strain can be calculated using the stress-strain relationship of the material, which is typically provided by the manufacturer.

#### 2.4c Truss Analysis

Truss analysis is a critical aspect of structural engineering, particularly in the design and analysis of bridges, roofs, and other structures that rely on trusses for support. The analysis involves determining the internal forces and deformations in the truss under various loading conditions. This information is then used to ensure that the truss can withstand the expected loads without deforming excessively or failing.

The analysis of a truss involves several steps. First, the truss is modeled in a structural analysis software. The model includes all the members of the truss, as well as any external loads and supports. The material properties of the members are also specified in the model.

Next, the model is analyzed using the finite element method. This method involves dividing the truss into a large number of small elements, and then solving the equations of equilibrium for each element. The results are then combined to obtain the internal forces and deformations in the truss.

The results of the analysis are then used to check the truss for excessive deformations and stresses. If the deformations or stresses are excessive, the truss is redesigned to reduce the deformations and stresses.

The analysis of a truss can be a complex task, especially for large and complex trusses. However, with the help of modern structural analysis software and the finite element method, the analysis can be performed efficiently and accurately.

In the next section, we will discuss the design of trusses, including the selection of the truss configuration, the sizing of the members, and the calculation of the internal forces and deformations.

#### 2.4d Truss Design

Truss design is a critical aspect of structural engineering, particularly in the design and construction of bridges, roofs, and other structures that rely on trusses for support. The design process involves selecting the truss configuration, sizing the members, and calculating the internal forces and deformations.

The first step in truss design is to select the truss configuration. The truss configuration refers to the arrangement of the members of the truss. The configuration is selected based on the structural requirements of the truss, including the magnitude and direction of the loads, the span of the truss, and the desired stiffness of the truss.

The most common truss configurations include the Howe truss, the Allan truss, and the Prussian truss. Each of these trusses has its own unique characteristics and applications. For example, the Howe truss is known for its strength and stiffness, making it suitable for long-span bridges. The Allan truss, on the other hand, is known for its simplicity and ease of construction, making it suitable for smaller structures.

The next step in truss design is to size the members. The sizing of the members involves determining the dimensions and material properties of the members. The dimensions of the members are determined based on the internal forces and deformations in the truss, as calculated in the truss analysis. The material properties of the members are determined based on the strength and stiffness requirements of the truss.

The final step in truss design is to calculate the internal forces and deformations. This is typically done using the results of the truss analysis. The internal forces and deformations are then used to check the truss for excessive deformations and stresses. If the deformations or stresses are excessive, the truss is redesigned to reduce the deformations and stresses.

The design of a truss can be a complex task, especially for large and complex trusses. However, with the help of modern structural analysis software and the finite element method, the design process can be made more efficient and accurate.

### Subsection 3.1a: Introduction to Deformable Bodies

In the previous chapters, we have discussed the mechanics of rigid bodies, where the deformation of the body is neglected. However, in many real-world applications, the deformation of the body cannot be ignored. This is where the mechanics of deformable bodies comes into play.

A deformable body is a body that can change its shape or size under the influence of external forces. This deformation can be elastic, where the body returns to its original shape after the external forces are removed, or plastic, where the deformation is permanent.

The study of mechanics of deformable bodies is crucial in many engineering disciplines, including civil, mechanical, and aerospace engineering. It is used to analyze and design structures, machines, and other systems that are subjected to external forces.

Finally, we will explore the applications of the mechanics of deformable bodies in various engineering fields, including structural analysis, machine design, and material selection.

#### 3.2a Definition of Multiaxial Stress

Multiaxial stress is a state of stress in which a body is subjected to stresses in more than one direction. This is in contrast to uniaxial stress, where the body is subjected to stresses in only one direction. In multiaxial stress, the stresses can be either symmetric or asymmetric, depending on the direction of the applied forces.

In the context of critical state soil mechanics, multiaxial stress is often encountered in soil and rock mechanics, where the soil or rock is subjected to stresses from various directions due to external forces such as gravity, wind, and traffic. The understanding of multiaxial stress is crucial in these fields, as it helps in predicting the behavior of the soil or rock under different loading conditions.

The mathematical representation of multiaxial stress is given by the stress tensor, which is a second-order tensor that relates the stress vector to the normal vector. For a three-dimensional body, the stress tensor is represented as:

$$
\sigma=\left[\begin{matrix}\sigma_{xx}&\tau_{xz}&\tau_{xy}\\\tau_{zx}&\sigma_{zz}&\tau_{yz}\\\tau_{xy}&\tau_{yz}&\sigma_{yy}\\\end{matrix}\right]
$$

where $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{zz}$, and $\sigma_{yy}$ are the normal stresses in the $x$, $z$, and $y$ directions, respectively, and $\tau_{xz}$, $\tau_{yz}$, and $\tau_{xy}$ are the shear stresses in the $xz$, $yz$, and $xy$ planes, respectively.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the analysis of multiaxial stress, focusing on the concepts of principal stresses and maximum shear stress.

#### 3.2b Types of Multiaxial Stress

Multiaxial stress can be broadly classified into two types: symmetric and asymmetric. 

##### Symmetric Multiaxial Stress

Symmetric multiaxial stress is a state of stress where the stress tensor is symmetric, i.e., the off-diagonal elements of the stress tensor are equal to each other. This type of stress is often encountered in structures that are subjected to uniform loading from all directions. The mathematical representation of symmetric multiaxial stress is given by the stress tensor:

$$
\sigma=\left[\begin{matrix}\sigma_{xx}&\tau_{xz}&\tau_{xy}\\\tau_{zx}&\sigma_{zz}&\tau_{yz}\\\tau_{xy}&\tau_{yz}&\sigma_{yy}\\\end{matrix}\right]
$$

where $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{zz}$, and $\sigma_{yy}$ are the normal stresses in the $x$, $z$, and $y$ directions, respectively, and $\tau_{xz}$, $\tau_{yz}$, and $\tau_{xy}$ are the shear stresses in the $xz$, $yz$, and $xy$ planes, respectively.

##### Asymmetric Multiaxial Stress

Asymmetric multiaxial stress is a state of stress where the stress tensor is asymmetric, i.e., the off-diagonal elements of the stress tensor are not equal to each other. This type of stress is often encountered in structures that are subjected to non-uniform loading from different directions. The mathematical representation of asymmetric multiaxial stress is given by the stress tensor:

$$
\sigma=\left[\begin{matrix}\sigma_{xx}&\tau_{xz}&\tau_{xy}\\\tau_{zx}&\sigma_{zz}&\tau_{yz}\\\tau_{xy}&\tau_{yz}&\sigma_{yy}\\\end{matrix}\right]
$$

where $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{zz}$, and $\sigma_{yy}$ are the normal stresses in the $x$, $z$, and $y$ directions, respectively, and $\tau_{xz}$, $\tau_{yz}$, and $\tau_{xy}$ are the shear stresses in the $xz$, $yz$, and $xy$ planes, respectively.

In the next section, we will discuss the concepts of principal stresses and maximum shear stress, which are crucial in understanding the behavior of structures under multiaxial stress.

#### 3.2c Applications of Multiaxial Stress

Multiaxial stress is a fundamental concept in the field of mechanics and materials, with wide-ranging applications in various engineering disciplines. This section will explore some of these applications, focusing on the design of structures and the analysis of deformation under multiaxial stress.

##### Structural Design

In structural design, multiaxial stress is a critical consideration. The type of multiaxial stress (symmetric or asymmetric) that a structure will experience depends on the type of loading it will be subjected to. For instance, a bridge may experience symmetric multiaxial stress under the weight of vehicles, while a building may experience asymmetric multiaxial stress under wind loading.

The understanding of multiaxial stress is crucial in the design of structures. It allows engineers to predict how a structure will deform under different types of loading, and to design the structure in such a way that it can withstand these deformations without failure.

##### Deformation Analysis

The analysis of deformation under multiaxial stress is another important application of this concept. As we have seen in the previous section, multiaxial stress can cause a body to deform in three ways: elongation, contraction, and shear. The amount of deformation that occurs depends on the type of stress (symmetric or asymmetric) and the material properties of the body.

For instance, consider a steel beam under multiaxial stress. If the stress is symmetric, the beam will experience elongation and contraction, but no shear. If the stress is asymmetric, the beam will experience shear in addition to elongation and contraction.

The understanding of multiaxial stress is crucial in the analysis of deformation. It allows engineers to predict how a body will deform under different types of loading, and to design structures that can withstand these deformations without failure.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the mathematical representation of multiaxial stress, and explore how this representation can be used to analyze deformation under multiaxial stress.




#### 3.2b Multiaxial Stress in Deformable Bodies

In the previous section, we discussed the types of multiaxial stress. Now, let's delve deeper into the concept of multiaxial stress in deformable bodies. 

##### Multiaxial Stress in Deformable Bodies

Deformable bodies are those that can change shape or size under the influence of external forces. When these bodies are subjected to multiaxial stress, the stress distribution within the body can be complex and non-uniform. This is due to the fact that the stresses in different directions can interact with each other, leading to a combination of normal and shear stresses.

The mathematical representation of multiaxial stress in deformable bodies is given by the stress tensor, as we have seen in the previous section. However, in the case of deformable bodies, the stress tensor can change with the deformation of the body. This is represented by the strain tensor, which relates the deformation of the body to the applied stress.

The strain tensor is given by:

$$
\epsilon=\left[\begin{matrix}\epsilon_{xx}&\gamma_{xz}&\gamma_{xy}\\\gamma_{zx}&\epsilon_{zz}&\gamma_{yz}\\\gamma_{xy}&\gamma_{yz}&\epsilon_{yy}\\\end{matrix}\right]
$$

where $\epsilon_{xx}$, $\epsilon_{zz}$, and $\epsilon_{yy}$ are the normal strains in the $x$, $z$, and $y$ directions, respectively, and $\gamma_{xz}$, $\gamma_{yz}$, and $\gamma_{xy}$ are the shear strains in the $xz$, $yz$, and $xy$ planes, respectively.

The relationship between the stress tensor and the strain tensor is given by the constitutive equations, which are specific to the material of the deformable body. These equations relate the stresses and strains, and are often non-linear for complex materials.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of multiaxial stress in deformable bodies in more detail, focusing on the effects of multiaxial stress on the deformation of the body.

#### 3.2c Solving Multiaxial Stress Problems

##### Solving Multiaxial Stress Problems

Solving multiaxial stress problems involves understanding the stress distribution within a deformable body under different loading conditions. This requires a thorough understanding of the stress tensor and the strain tensor, as well as the constitutive equations that relate the stresses and strains.

The first step in solving a multiaxial stress problem is to determine the stress tensor. This can be done by applying the principles of equilibrium and compatibility to the body. The stress tensor can then be used to calculate the strain tensor, which represents the deformation of the body under the applied stress.

The next step is to use the constitutive equations to relate the stresses and strains. These equations are often non-linear and may require numerical methods to solve. The solution to the constitutive equations gives the deformation of the body under the applied stress.

Finally, the deformation of the body can be compared to the actual deformation to verify the solution. This involves calculating the strain energy and comparing it to the work done by the external forces. If the strain energy is equal to the work done, the solution is correct.

#### 3.3a Definition of Multiaxial Strain

Multiaxial strain is a concept that extends the principles of uniaxial strain to more complex loading conditions. In uniaxial strain, a material is subjected to a single applied stress in a single direction. However, in multiaxial strain, a material is subjected to multiple applied stresses in multiple directions. This can occur in a variety of engineering applications, such as in the design of structures or machines.

The strain tensor, which describes the deformation of a material under stress, becomes more complex in multiaxial strain. The strain tensor is a second-order tensor, and in multiaxial strain, it can have non-zero components in multiple directions. This is in contrast to uniaxial strain, where the strain tensor is a scalar quantity.

The strain tensor can be represented as a 3x3 matrix, with each component representing the strain in a particular direction. For example, the strain tensor for a material under multiaxial stress can be represented as:

$$
\epsilon = \begin{bmatrix}
\epsilon_{xx} & \epsilon_{xy} & \epsilon_{xz} \\
\epsilon_{yx} & \epsilon_{yy} & \epsilon_{yz} \\
\epsilon_{zx} & \epsilon_{zy} & \epsilon_{zz}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

where $\epsilon_{ij}$ represents the strain in direction $i$ due to stress in direction $j$.

The strain tensor can also be represented in a more compact form using vector notation. In this form, the strain tensor is represented as a vector of nine components, with each component representing the strain in a particular direction. For example, the strain tensor for a material under multiaxial stress can be represented as:

$$
\epsilon = \begin{bmatrix}
\epsilon_{xx} & \epsilon_{xy} & \epsilon_{xz} \\
\epsilon_{yx} & \epsilon_{yy} & \epsilon_{yz} \\
\epsilon_{zx} & \epsilon_{zy} & \epsilon_{zz}
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
\epsilon_{xx} & \epsilon_{xy} & \epsilon_{xz} \\
\epsilon_{yx} & \epsilon_{yy} & \epsilon_{yz} \\
\epsilon_{zx} & \epsilon_{zy} & \epsilon_{zz}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

In the next section, we will explore the relationship between multiaxial strain and multiaxial stress, and how this relationship can be used to analyze the behavior of materials under different loading conditions.

#### 3.3b Multiaxial Strain Calculation

The calculation of multiaxial strain involves the application of the strain tensor. As we have seen, the strain tensor is a 3x3 matrix, with each component representing the strain in a particular direction. The calculation of multiaxial strain involves the application of this tensor to the stress tensor.

The strain tensor can be calculated from the stress tensor using the strain-displacement relationship. This relationship is given by:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{1}{2} \left( \nabla u + (\nabla u)^T \right)
$$

where $\epsilon$ is the strain tensor, $u$ is the displacement vector, and $T$ denotes the transpose of a matrix.

The strain-displacement relationship can be used to calculate the strain tensor for a material under multiaxial stress. This involves calculating the displacement vector for each direction of stress, and then applying the strain-displacement relationship to obtain the strain tensor.

For example, consider a material under multiaxial stress with stress components $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{yy}$, and $\sigma_{zz}$. The displacement vector for this material can be calculated as:

$$
u = \begin{bmatrix}
u_x \\
u_y \\
u_z
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

where $E$ is the modulus of elasticity.

Substituting this displacement vector into the strain-displacement relationship, we obtain the strain tensor for this material under multiaxial stress:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{1}{2} \left( \nabla u + (\nabla u)^T \right) = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{yx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{zx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

This strain tensor can then be used to calculate the strain in any direction. For example, the strain in the $x$ direction can be calculated as:

$$
\epsilon_{xx} = \frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{xy}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{xz}}{E}
$$

In the next section, we will explore the relationship between multiaxial strain and multiaxial stress, and how this relationship can be used to analyze the behavior of materials under different loading conditions.

#### 3.3c Multiaxial Strain Examples

In this section, we will explore some examples of multiaxial strain to further understand the concepts discussed in the previous sections.

##### Example 1: Strain Tensor Calculation

Consider a material under multiaxial stress with stress components $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{yy}$, and $\sigma_{zz}$. The strain tensor for this material can be calculated as follows:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{1}{2} \left( \nabla u + (\nabla u)^T \right) = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{yx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{zx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

where $E$ is the modulus of elasticity.

##### Example 2: Strain in Different Directions

The strain in the $x$ direction can be calculated as:

$$
\epsilon_{xx} = \frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{xy}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{xz}}{E}
$$

The strain in the $y$ direction can be calculated as:

$$
\epsilon_{yy} = \frac{\sigma_{yx}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{yz}}{E}
$$

The strain in the $z$ direction can be calculated as:

$$
\epsilon_{zz} = \frac{\sigma_{zx}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{zy}}{E} + \frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
$$

##### Example 3: Strain-Displacement Relationship

The strain-displacement relationship can be used to calculate the strain tensor for a material under multiaxial stress. This involves calculating the displacement vector for each direction of stress, and then applying the strain-displacement relationship to obtain the strain tensor.

For example, consider a material under multiaxial stress with stress components $\sigma_{xx}$, $\sigma_{yy}$, and $\sigma_{zz}$. The displacement vector for this material can be calculated as:

$$
u = \begin{bmatrix}
u_x \\
u_y \\
u_z
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Substituting this displacement vector into the strain-displacement relationship, we obtain the strain tensor for this material under multiaxial stress:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{1}{2} \left( \nabla u + (\nabla u)^T \right) = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{\sigma_{xx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{xz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{yx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{yz}}{E} \\
\frac{\sigma_{zx}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zy}}{E} & \frac{\sigma_{zz}}{E}
\end{bmatrix}
$$

These examples should help you understand the concepts of multiaxial strain and how they are calculated. In the next section, we will explore the relationship between multiaxial strain and multiaxial stress, and how this relationship can be used to analyze the behavior of materials under different loading conditions.

## Chapter 4: Deformation of Elastic Bodies

### Introduction

In the realm of mechanics, the study of deformation of elastic bodies is a fundamental concept that forms the basis of understanding the behavior of materials under different loading conditions. This chapter, "Deformation of Elastic Bodies," delves into the intricacies of this topic, providing a comprehensive understanding of the principles and applications of elastic deformation.

Elastic deformation is a phenomenon that occurs when a material is subjected to external forces, causing it to change shape. However, unlike plastic deformation, elastic deformation is reversible. This means that once the external forces are removed, the material returns to its original shape. This property is what makes elastic materials so valuable in engineering applications.

In this chapter, we will explore the mathematical models that describe elastic deformation. These models, expressed in terms of stress and strain, are fundamental to understanding the behavior of elastic bodies under different loading conditions. We will also discuss the concept of Hooke's Law, a fundamental principle in the study of elastic deformation.

Furthermore, we will delve into the concept of strain energy, a crucial concept in the study of elastic deformation. Strain energy is the energy stored in a material due to deformation, and it plays a significant role in the behavior of elastic bodies under different loading conditions.

Finally, we will discuss the concept of deformation compatibility, a concept that is crucial in the study of elastic deformation. Deformation compatibility is a condition that must be satisfied for the deformation of an elastic body to be continuous and smooth.

By the end of this chapter, you will have a solid understanding of the principles and applications of elastic deformation. This knowledge will serve as a foundation for the subsequent chapters, where we will delve deeper into the mechanics of deformable bodies.




#### 3.3b Multiaxial Stress-strain Relationships

Multiaxial stress-strain relationships are a crucial aspect of understanding the behavior of materials under complex loading conditions. These relationships describe how a material responds to different types of stress, and they are essential for predicting the deformation and failure of materials under various loading conditions.

The stress-strain relationship for a material under multiaxial stress can be represented as a function of the strain tensor $\epsilon$ and the stress tensor $\sigma$. This function, known as the constitutive equation, describes the relationship between stress and strain for a particular material. The constitutive equation can be represented as:

$$
\sigma = f(\epsilon)
$$

where $f$ is a function that describes the stress-strain relationship for the material.

In the case of a linear elastic material, the constitutive equation can be represented as:

$$
\sigma = E \epsilon
$$

where $E$ is the elastic modulus, a material property that describes the stiffness of the material.

For a more general case, the constitutive equation can be represented as:

$$
\sigma = C \epsilon
$$

where $C$ is the elasticity tensor, a fourth-order tensor that describes the relationship between stress and strain for a material.

The elasticity tensor is a crucial component of the multiaxial stress-strain relationship. It is a 4th-order tensor, and its components can be represented as:

$$
C_{ijkl} = \frac{\partial \sigma_{ij}}{\partial \epsilon_{kl}}
$$

where $C_{ijkl}$ is the component of the elasticity tensor in the $i$th, $j$th, $k$th, and $l$th directions, and $\sigma_{ij}$ and $\epsilon_{kl}$ are the components of the stress and strain tensors, respectively.

The elasticity tensor is symmetric, meaning that $C_{ijkl} = C_{klij}$. This symmetry is a result of the physical properties of materials, and it simplifies the analysis of multiaxial stress-strain relationships.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of strain energy density and its role in the multiaxial stress-strain relationship.

#### 3.3c Applications of Multiaxial Strain

Multiaxial strain is a fundamental concept in the field of mechanics and materials, with wide-ranging applications in various engineering disciplines. This section will explore some of these applications, focusing on the use of multiaxial strain in the design and analysis of structures and machines.

##### Structural Analysis

In structural analysis, multiaxial strain is used to predict the deformation and failure of structures under complex loading conditions. For instance, in the design of a bridge, engineers must consider the effects of multiaxial strain on the bridge's structural elements. This is typically done using the principles of statics and the equations of equilibrium, which can be represented as:

$$
\sum F = 0
$$

$$
\sum M = 0
$$

where $F$ and $M$ are the forces and moments acting on the structure, respectively.

##### Machine Design

In machine design, multiaxial strain is used to analyze the stress and strain in machine components under various operating conditions. For example, in the design of a rotating machine, engineers must consider the effects of multiaxial strain on the machine's rotating components. This is typically done using the principles of dynamics and the equations of motion, which can be represented as:

$$
\sum F = m \cdot a
$$

$$
\sum M = I \cdot \alpha
$$

where $F$ and $M$ are the forces and moments acting on the machine, respectively, $m$ is the mass of the machine, $a$ is the acceleration of the machine, $I$ is the moment of inertia of the machine, and $\alpha$ is the angular acceleration of the machine.

##### Material Testing

In material testing, multiaxial strain is used to measure the mechanical properties of materials under various loading conditions. For instance, in a tensile test, a material is subjected to a uniaxial tensile stress, and the resulting strain is measured. The stress-strain relationship for the material can then be determined, which can be represented as:

$$
\sigma = f(\epsilon)
$$

where $\sigma$ is the stress, $\epsilon$ is the strain, and $f$ is the constitutive equation for the material.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the concept of multiaxial strain, exploring its mathematical representation and the principles that govern its behavior.




#### 3.3c Solving Multiaxial Strain Problems

In the previous sections, we have discussed the multiaxial stress-strain relationships and the elasticity tensor. Now, we will delve into the practical application of these concepts by learning how to solve multiaxial strain problems.

The first step in solving any multiaxial strain problem is to understand the loading conditions. This includes the type of loading (e.g., tensile, compressive, bending), the magnitude of the applied forces, and the direction of these forces. 

Next, we need to determine the material properties. This includes the elastic modulus $E$, the Poisson's ratio $\nu$, and the yield strength $Y$. These properties are typically provided in the problem statement or can be looked up in material databases.

Once we have the loading conditions and material properties, we can use the constitutive equation to calculate the stress tensor $\sigma$. For a linear elastic material, this is simply:

$$
\sigma = E \epsilon
$$

where $\epsilon$ is the strain tensor. The strain tensor can be calculated from the deformation gradient tensor $F$, which is a function of the displacement field $u$. The deformation gradient tensor is given by:

$$
F = I + \Gamma
$$

where $I$ is the identity tensor and $\Gamma$ is the gradient tensor. The gradient tensor is a function of the displacement field $u$ and is given by:

$$
\Gamma = \nabla u
$$

The strain tensor $\epsilon$ can then be calculated from the deformation gradient tensor $F$ using the deformation gradient formula:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}(F + F^T - I)(F + F^T - I)^T
$$

where $F^T$ is the transpose of the deformation gradient tensor.

Finally, we can use the stress-strain relationship to calculate the strain energy density function $W$. The strain energy density function is given by:

$$
W = \frac{1}{2}\sigma:\epsilon
$$

where $\sigma:\epsilon$ is the double dot product of the stress and strain tensors.

By solving these equations, we can determine the stress and strain in a material under multiaxial loading conditions. This is a crucial step in understanding the behavior of materials under complex loading conditions and predicting the deformation and failure of materials.

In the next section, we will discuss some examples of multiaxial strain problems and how to solve them.




#### 3.4a Stress-strain-temperature Relationships

In the previous sections, we have discussed the multiaxial stress-strain relationships and the elasticity tensor. Now, we will explore the stress-strain-temperature relationships, which are crucial in understanding the behavior of materials under different temperature conditions.

The stress-strain-temperature relationships are governed by the material's thermal expansion properties. These properties describe how a material's dimensions change in response to a change in temperature. The most common thermal expansion properties are the coefficient of thermal expansion and the thermal strain.

The coefficient of thermal expansion ($\alpha$) is defined as the fractional change in length or volume of a material per degree change in temperature. It is typically expressed in units of length per length per degree Celsius (or Kelvin) or volume per volume per degree Celsius (or Kelvin). The thermal strain ($\epsilon_T$), on the other hand, is the strain induced by a change in temperature.

The stress-strain-temperature relationships can be described by the following equations:

$$
\sigma = E \epsilon + \alpha \Delta T
$$

$$
\epsilon_T = \alpha \Delta T
$$

where $\sigma$ is the stress, $E$ is the elastic modulus, $\epsilon$ is the strain, $\alpha$ is the coefficient of thermal expansion, $\Delta T$ is the change in temperature, and $\epsilon_T$ is the thermal strain.

These equations show that the stress and strain in a material are influenced by both the applied load and the change in temperature. The coefficient of thermal expansion acts as a material property that determines the magnitude of the thermal strain.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of thin-walled pressure vessels and how the stress-strain-temperature relationships apply to these structures.

#### 3.4b Thin-walled Pressure Vessels

Thin-walled pressure vessels are containers designed to hold fluids or gases at a pressure that is significantly different from the ambient pressure. These vessels are used in a variety of industries, including chemical, petroleum, and nuclear power. Understanding the stress-strain-temperature relationships is crucial in the design and analysis of these vessels.

The stress in a thin-walled pressure vessel is primarily due to the internal pressure and the change in temperature. The internal pressure causes a hoop stress, while the change in temperature induces a thermal stress. The hoop stress ($\sigma_{\theta}$) and the longitudinal stress ($\sigma_z$) can be calculated using the following equations:

$$
\sigma_{\theta} = \frac{pr}{t}
$$

$$
\sigma_z = \frac{pr}{2t}
$$

where $p$ is the internal pressure, $r$ is the radius, and $t$ is the thickness of the vessel.

The thermal stress ($\sigma_T$) can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\sigma_T = \alpha \Delta T
$$

where $\alpha$ is the coefficient of thermal expansion and $\Delta T$ is the change in temperature.

The total stress ($\sigma_{total}$) in the vessel is the sum of the hoop stress, the longitudinal stress, and the thermal stress:

$$
\sigma_{total} = \sigma_{\theta} + \sigma_z + \sigma_T
$$

The strain in the vessel can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\epsilon = \frac{\sigma_{total}}{E}
$$

where $E$ is the elastic modulus of the material.

The strain induced by the change in temperature ($\epsilon_T$) can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\epsilon_T = \alpha \Delta T
$$

The total strain ($\epsilon_{total}$) in the vessel is the sum of the strain induced by the applied load and the strain induced by the change in temperature:

$$
\epsilon_{total} = \epsilon + \epsilon_T
$$

The deformation of the vessel can be calculated using the following equation:

$$
\delta = \epsilon_{total} \cdot r
$$

where $\delta$ is the deformation of the vessel.

In the next section, we will discuss the design considerations for thin-walled pressure vessels and how the stress-strain-temperature relationships apply to these vessels.

#### 3.4b Thin-walled Pressure Vessels

Thin-walled pressure vessels are containers designed to hold fluids or gases at a pressure that is significantly higher than the ambient pressure. These vessels are used in a variety of industries, including chemical, petroleum, and nuclear, to store and transport substances under high pressure. The design of these vessels is critical to ensure their safe and efficient operation.

The stress in thin-walled pressure vessels can be calculated using the following equations:

$$
\sigma_\theta = \frac{pr}{t}
$$

$$
\sigma_{long} = \frac{pr}{2t}
$$

where $\sigma_\theta$ is the hoop stress, $\sigma_{long}$ is the longitudinal stress, $p$ is the internal gauge pressure, $r$ is the inner radius of the vessel, and $t$ is the thickness of the vessel wall.

These equations assume that the vessel is thin-walled, meaning that the diameter is at least 10 times greater than the wall thickness. This assumption simplifies the analysis of stress in the vessel.

The ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code (BPVC) provides more detailed equations for calculating stress in thin-walled pressure vessels. These equations account for variations in stress across the thickness of the vessel, the quality of welds, and in-service corrosion allowances. The equations also include a factor of safety to account for uncertainties in the design and construction of the vessel.

For example, the ASME BPVC (UG-27) formulas for spherical shells are:

$$
\sigma_\theta = \frac{pr}{t} \cdot \frac{E}{1-(\frac{r}{t})^2}
$$

$$
\sigma_{long} = \frac{pr}{2t} \cdot \frac{E}{1-(\frac{r}{t})^2}
$$

where $E$ is the joint efficiency, and all other variables are as stated above.

These equations show that the stress in a thin-walled pressure vessel is dependent on the internal pressure, the vessel's dimensions, and the material properties. The design of a pressure vessel must therefore take into account these factors to ensure that the vessel can withstand the expected pressures without exceeding its design limits.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of thin-walled pressure vessels in more detail, including their design considerations and the factors that influence their performance.




#### 3.4c Solving Thin-walled Pressure Vessel Problems

The design of thin-walled pressure vessels involves solving complex problems that involve stress analysis, material selection, and dimensional design. This section will provide a step-by-step guide to solving these problems.

##### Step 1: Define the Problem

The first step in solving any problem is to clearly define the problem. This involves understanding the purpose of the vessel, the expected operating conditions, and any constraints on the design. For example, a pressure vessel for a chemical plant may need to withstand high pressures and corrosive substances, while a vessel for a nuclear reactor may need to withstand high temperatures and neutron radiation.

##### Step 2: Select the Material

The next step is to select the material for the vessel. This is typically done based on the operating conditions and any constraints on the design. For example, a vessel for a chemical plant may be made of a strong and corrosion-resistant material like stainless steel, while a vessel for a nuclear reactor may be made of a high-temperature and radiation-resistant material like austenitic stainless steel.

##### Step 3: Determine the Dimensions

The dimensions of the vessel are determined based on the operating conditions and the material properties. This involves calculating the thickness of the vessel wall, the inner and outer diameters, and the length of the vessel. The ASME BPVC provides detailed equations for calculating these dimensions, such as the equations for spherical shells and cylindrical shells mentioned in the previous section.

##### Step 4: Calculate the Stress

Once the dimensions of the vessel are determined, the stress in the vessel can be calculated. This involves applying the equations for hoop stress and longitudinal stress, as well as any additional equations from the ASME BPVC. The stress should be compared to the material's yield strength to ensure that the vessel can withstand the expected operating conditions.

##### Step 5: Check the Design

The final step is to check the design of the vessel. This involves verifying that the vessel meets all the design constraints, such as the maximum allowable stress and the minimum wall thickness. If the design does not meet these constraints, the dimensions or the material may need to be adjusted.

In conclusion, the design of thin-walled pressure vessels involves a series of steps that require a deep understanding of mechanics, materials, and stress analysis. By following these steps, engineers can design vessels that are safe, efficient, and reliable.

In conclusion, the study of mechanics of deformable bodies is a complex but rewarding field. It provides the foundation for understanding the behavior of structures under various conditions, and it is essential in the design and analysis of structures.

### Exercises

#### Exercise 1
Calculate the stress in a steel rod of diameter 10 mm and length 2 m, when a force of 10 kN is applied at one end. Assume that the steel has a Young's modulus of 200 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.3.

#### Exercise 2
A beam of length 3 m and cross-sectional area 0.1 m$^2$ is subjected to a bending moment of 50 kN$\cdot$m. If the beam is made of a material with a yield strength of 300 MPa, calculate the maximum stress in the beam.

#### Exercise 3
A cylindrical pressure vessel of diameter 1 m and wall thickness 10 mm is subjected to an internal pressure of 5 MPa. If the vessel is made of a material with a Young's modulus of 150 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.3, calculate the hoop stress and the longitudinal stress in the vessel.

#### Exercise 4
A cantilever beam of length 2 m and cross-sectional area 0.05 m$^2$ is subjected to a uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m. If the beam is made of a material with a Young's modulus of 200 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.3, calculate the maximum deflection of the beam.

#### Exercise 5
A steel column of length 4 m and cross-sectional area 0.1 m$^2$ is subjected to an axial load of 500 kN. If the steel has a Young's modulus of 200 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.3, calculate the critical load at which the column will buckle.

## Chapter: Mechanics of Deformable Bodies - Introduction

### Introduction

In the realm of mechanics, the study of deformable bodies is a fascinating and complex field. This chapter, "Mechanics of Deformable Bodies - Introduction," aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the fundamental principles and concepts that govern the behavior of deformable bodies under various conditions.

Deformable bodies are objects that can change shape or size when subjected to external forces. They are ubiquitous in our daily lives, from the flexible plastic containers we use to store food, to the metal beams that support the roof of our houses. Understanding the mechanics of these bodies is crucial for engineers and scientists who design and analyze structures and machines.

In this chapter, we will delve into the basic principles of deformable bodies, starting with the concept of stress and strain. We will explore how these quantities are defined and how they are related to each other. We will also discuss the different types of stress and strain, and how they can be calculated.

We will then move on to the concept of deformation, which is the change in shape or size of a body when subjected to external forces. We will learn about the different types of deformation, such as elastic deformation and plastic deformation, and how they can be measured.

Finally, we will introduce the concept of material properties, which describe the response of a material to external forces. We will learn about the different types of material properties, such as Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio, and how they can be used to predict the behavior of deformable bodies.

This chapter will provide a solid foundation for the subsequent chapters, where we will delve deeper into the mechanics of deformable bodies, exploring topics such as the theory of elasticity, plasticity, and fracture mechanics. By the end of this chapter, you should have a good understanding of the basic principles of deformable bodies, and be ready to explore more advanced topics.

## Chapter 3: Mechanics of Deformable Bodies - Introduction:

### Conclusion

In this chapter, we have explored the mechanics of deformable bodies, a crucial aspect of mechanics and materials. We have delved into the fundamental principles that govern the behavior of deformable bodies under various loading conditions. We have also examined the concept of stress and strain, and how they are related to the deformation of a body.

We have learned that deformable bodies are those that can change shape or size when subjected to external forces. This is in contrast to rigid bodies, which do not deform under load. The understanding of deformable bodies is essential in many engineering applications, including the design of structures and machines.

We have also introduced the concept of stress, which is a measure of the internal forces within a body. Stress is a crucial concept in mechanics as it helps us understand how a body responds to external forces. We have learned that stress is directly related to strain, which is a measure of the deformation of a body. This relationship is described by Hooke's Law, which states that the strain in a body is directly proportional to the applied stress within the elastic limit of that body.

In addition, we have explored the concept of strain, which is a measure of the deformation of a body. Strain is a crucial concept in mechanics as it helps us understand how a body deforms under load. We have learned that strain is directly related to stress, and this relationship is described by Hooke's Law.

Finally, we have introduced the concept of deformation, which is a change in shape or size of a body when subjected to external forces. Deformation is a crucial concept in mechanics as it helps us understand how a body responds to external forces. We have learned that deformation is directly related to stress and strain, and this relationship is described by Hooke's Law.

In conclusion, the mechanics of deformable bodies is a complex and fascinating field that is essential in many engineering applications. By understanding the principles of stress, strain, and deformation, we can design and analyze structures and machines that can withstand external forces.

## Chapter 4: Pure Bending:

### Introduction

In the previous chapters, we have explored the fundamental concepts of statics, strength of materials, and deformable bodies. We have learned about the behavior of materials under different loading conditions and how to analyze and design structures to withstand these loads. In this chapter, we will delve deeper into the concept of pure bending, a type of loading that occurs when a structure is subjected to equal and opposite bending moments.

Pure bending is a critical aspect of structural analysis and design. It is encountered in a wide range of engineering applications, from the design of bridges and buildings to the manufacturing of machine components. Understanding the principles of pure bending is essential for engineers and scientists to ensure the safety and reliability of structures and machines.

In this chapter, we will explore the theory of pure bending, starting with the basic concepts and gradually moving on to more complex topics. We will learn about the different types of bending moments, the bending stress and strain, and the bending formula. We will also discuss the concept of neutral axis and how it affects the distribution of stresses in a bent element.

Furthermore, we will delve into the analysis of pure bending in different types of materials, including ductile and brittle materials. We will learn about the yield criteria for pure bending and how to determine the maximum load a structure can withstand before failure.

Finally, we will discuss the practical applications of pure bending, including the design of beams, columns, and other structural elements. We will learn how to calculate the required dimensions and material properties to ensure the structural integrity of these elements.

By the end of this chapter, you will have a comprehensive understanding of pure bending and its applications. You will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to analyze and design structures under pure bending conditions, ensuring their safety and reliability. So, let's dive into the world of pure bending and explore its fascinating principles and applications.

This results in the body experiencing a combination of tensile and compressive stresses, with the neutral axis acting as the line of zero stress. We have also seen how the bending moment is related to the second moment of area, and how this relationship can be used to calculate the maximum stress and deflection in a bent body.

This formula is a powerful tool that can be used to analyze and design structures under pure bending.

In conclusion, pure bending is a complex phenomenon that is governed by a set of fundamental principles. By understanding these principles and how they apply to different types of structures, we can design and analyze structures that are safe and efficient.
